subject: requester: PLDM handler for async request/response
commitMessage:
requester: PLDM handler for async request/response

PLDM request handler provides APIs to register PLDM request message,
handle retries and instance ID expiration. Sending the PLDM request
and handling response is handled in an async manner. On receiving
the response the corresponding response handler registered for the
request is invoked.

Tested: Ran unit tests

Signed-off-by: Tom Joseph <rushtotom@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I9f0a9dfcf0fbc9a84eefad375b92d40dd8b48d3d

i have a question. how does the solution work for cases where the pldm_send_recv is not called from an object which is sustained throughout the timeline of pldmd
like:
oem/ibm/libpldmresponder/platform_oem_ibm.cpp: sendBiosAttributeUpdateEvent: pldm_send_recv is used here. but the function will not be alive when the response arrives

Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 74f27c730ef3925a0f2a3adfaa04f8790f931372 by ManojKiran Eda
this also needs to be changed right?
Yup, I made change at one place as an example.
Don't have a test setup for the PDR exchange flow, feel free to use the requester APIs for code that uses pldm_send_recv and create patches.
does it accept the event class or the command? PLDM_PLATFORM_EVENT_MESSAGE?
This is a broad API, taking the PLDM type/command. Any eventClass data can be encoded using the libpldm API's and passed as requestMsg.

is "retry" a mandatory feature?
should we not have an option to disable it as well?

Yes, feel free to pass it as 0 in the bbappend file. PLDM base specification mentions 2 as min.

I wrote a test for that https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/pldm/+/43465/3/requester/test/request_test.cpp#1
rephrase? not following this.
Ack
Can you also update the README with some details?
Ack
not sure I followed, why should the response handler be invoked in this case? can you add details?
I have added the details in the README.
what about error logging?

Is the suggestion to have an error log/trace to journal to indicate that no response is received? We can definitely do that. At the same time, the command handlers will typically do the appropriate actions/tracing.

No response received and request times out - yes that must be logged. Also, hopefully response handlers handle this empty response gracefully. What is the actual purpose of calling the response handler here? Maybe you can add that in a comment as well.

Sure, will add tracing.

> What is the actual purpose of calling the response handler here?
So that whatever business logic can kick in. For example report failure of a firmware update or  initiate it from the beginning.
Should we assert here?
Ack
Should check for some kind of limit here - instance id is just 5 bits.

Is the question, do we need to validate the instance id passed into registerRequest?

We can do that additional check, i didn't add that in the first place thinking the user will be using the Requester API and the sanity of that code.

Which Requester API do you mean?

More than checking the value of the input instanceId, my question was what do we do if the map already contains 2^5 requests? Generalizing that - how do we deal with the case where a key already exists?

With the current implementation if the key( a combination of eid, instanceId, type, command) exists, then the new entry is not entered in the map, as the emplace will return the existing entry.

But for practical purposes, the instanceID timer expiry will kick in and free the instance IDs.
typo
Why would we need this?

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/pldm/+/43465/5/pldmd/pldmd.cpp#b104

When other applications like softoff & openpower-occ-control, get the instance ID, it was freed by the pldm daemon(link above). Freeing the instance id is moved to the handleResponse in the requester portion.

Ideally freeing the instance id requested by other application should not be done by pldm daemon and freed by the application itself. But the D-Bus API doesn't give that provision. So this might need more discussion.
isn't this a fixed value in the spec? who passes this value?
Time-out waiting for a response has a min and max in the base specification(300ms- 4800ms). This is provided as a meson option with a default value to facilitate a couple of retries.
What happens if we get a response message after this?

If the response comes in the window when the retries are done(timer is stopped) and the instance ID is not yet expired. The response handler is invoked with the response.

If the instance id expires then the handler is called with null response.

If the response is received beyond the instance id expiration, response is ignored. (instance id is currently marked free to handle the softoff/openpower-occ-control).
